title: How Treasury Wine is weathering the trade war
text:
But Clarke says TWE’s position is much stronger than many of his rivals, because of its strategy to go around the big wine agents and distributors and sell directly to retailers.

Along with Clarke’s focus on more premium wine – bottles costing more than $10 now account for 70 per cent of sales, up from 43 per cent five years ago – this direct-to-market strategy has been central to TWE’s transformation over the past five years. He proudly calls Treasury the most self-distributed wine company in the world.

Fatter margins

Bypassing the distributors in China, who take a margin of up to 60 per cent, means Treasury’s own margins are stronger than its rivals. Its Asian margin in 2018-19 was 39.2 per cent, up 170 basis points, and almost double its margin in the US.

So during this period of destocking, where the big distributors are getting caught with too much inventory, TWE can afford to maintain spending on marketing (particularly via what Clarke calls key opinion leaders) and so-called pull through promotions, which typically involve offering giving consumer a wine glass or two with their bottle of plonk.

The elevated marketing spending helps entrench TWE’s wines in consumers' minds. And this helps generate sales for Chinese retailers who might be doing it tougher in an economy hit by trade tensions.

“Our product in retail stores is converting to cash quicker than any other brand,” Clarke tells Chanticleer.

Defending channel-stuffing allegations

Advertisement

Tuesday’s investor day was very much about highlighting TWE’s growth trajectory over the past five years, which has seen group EBIT increase from $225 million to $663 million, its EBIT margin rise from 12.1 per cent to 23.4 per cent, and TWE’s stock price jump by almost 300 per cent.

But the Chinese market is also home to one of the big controversies around Treasury’s growth over the period: persistent allegations that it has engaged in “channel stuffing” in China.

The claims stem from what Clarke calls TWE's portfolio approach to imports. This means Chinese retailers who want to get their hands on a shipping container filled with lots of the top-selling Penfolds brand also need to buy other TWE brands.

Clarke says this is to ensure Treasury doesn’t end up with all its eggs in the Penfolds basket. But it’s led to claims TWE has effectively forced its less popular brands on retailers who really don’t want them – and this has inflated TWE’s Asian sales.

Clarke has a passionate three-point defence to the claims.

Firstly, Treasury allocates its wine vintages over a five-year cycle that is fully audited, and not tampered with to suddenly dump stock. Secondly, its direct-to-retail approach means it couldn’t channel stuff even if it wanted to, as retailers always want to keep stock levels low. Finally, shipments of wine and depletions from inventory are in balance.

The channel stuffing noise clearly grates with Clarke. But he concedes that Treasury’s Chinese selling strategy isn’t perfect and he says North Asia boss Tom King will work more closely with Chinese retailers to lift sales across TWE’s portfolio.

King will do this, in part, by developing joint business plans with retailers – a strategy popular in Europe, where King was previously posted.

Clarke is also expanding Treasury’s warehouse model in China. This will lessen the need for sales of containers full of wine – which take up to eight weeks to get to China, and are sold on credit terms of 90 days – and give TWE the ability to deliver smaller, more bespoke orders on credit terms of 45 days.
description: Michael Clarke's strategy of dodging the wine industry's middlemen is helping it win in a Chinese economy hit by the trade war.
